Description: Egyptian terracotta figure plaque. Mould-made plaque in raised relief of a frontal nude female figure (Isis-Hathor?) wearing a short wig standing within a portico upheld by two pillars. Mould-made and solid with plain flat back. Light brown surface (slip?). Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core with abundant organic vesicles, common fine quartz, mica and white inclusions. Broken at waist, bottom half lost.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Unprovenanced (probably Naukratis?) parallel from the same mopuld series (Petrie Museum UC30191 and 8, see also similar UC30190 and UC30193). Terracotta plaque of nude female figure in Egyptian shrine. Variants from Naukratis (Higgins 1954, 404, no.1542; Gutch 1899, 82, nos. 51-55) include examples depicted without pillars (Type Thomas P-F.3.1:Alexandria 16903; Boston 86.389; Brussels E.5018; Oxford AN1896-1908-E.4681; AN1896-1908-E.4680; Cambridge NA583) and with pillars supporting lintel (Type Thomas P-F.3.2, AN1896-1908-E.4678), with an Phoenician amphora or other vessel (Type Thomas P-F.3.3, British Museum 1886,0401.1543 ; Brussels A.1849; Boston 86.395), with lotus or Hathor capitals (Type Thomas P-F.3.4, Oxford AN1896-1908-E.4680; AN1896-1908-E.4679; Bristol H2223.b; Cambridge NA582; NA578; 1886,0401.1543 Amsterdam 7483) and with a child (P-F.3.5, Boston 86.900; Cambridge NA580). Parallels from Memphis (Petrie Museum UC30186-8; Ashton 2003a, 73; Petrie 1909a, pl.xxxv, no. 6, 7, 12; Rotté 2012, 13; see also Dunand 1973, 20-1; Thomas & Nicholson 201346, P-11, P-10; Petrie Museum UC50489; UC30186-8; probably UC30190-9), Saqqara (Hastings 1997, 66, pl.63, no.251). 5th to 3rd century BC Mendes (Redford 1991, 67, pl. 22d; Redford 2004, 129, no. 764; Redford 2010, fig.13.10), 5th century BC Tell el-Balamun (Spencer 1996, pl.78, no.79), Nebesheh (Petrie 1888, pl.7), Ashmunein (Roeder 1959, pl.58.p, n, o and q; pl.47.f and G), Tanis (but in faience Brissaud 1994. Fig.8d) and unprovenanced (in Bonn, Schmidt 1997, no. 175, Pl.56, D 57; Petrie Museum UC30189-99 are very similar to Naukratis pieces and may also have come from Naukratis; Török 1995, 137-9, pl. 108, nos. 203-5; Kaufmann 1913, 100-3, fig. 69,1; 1915, 107-9, no. 268; Bayer Niemeier 1988, 148-9, pl. 50, no. 267; Weber 1914, no.199). This appears to be a Persian period type found mainly in Lower Egypt that shows influences from Achaemenid period Phoenician sites in the Levant (Pruss 2000, 52-4; Rotté 2012, 13) on the indigenous Egyptian ‘fertility’ figure types (Pinch 1983; 1993; 2006; Teeter 2010) and contemporary with examples in limestone (Type Thomas L-F.2). Dated broadly end of 6th century BC to 4th century BC, though may continue into 3rd century BC. Ashton, S-A. 2003. Petrie's Ptolemaic and Roman Memphis. London: Institute of Archaeology, UCL.
